close_symbols: OS_Application_Startup (caller and its call-site(s) passing Status)
All other call-sites of OS_ApplicationExit (if any)
explanation:
- OS_SUCCESS: The controlling expression is (Status == OS_SUCCESS). You must know the definition/value of OS_SUCCESS (macro or enum) to determine whether the comparison can ever be true or false or reduces to a constant expression.
- int32 (typedef): The parameter type may carry qualifiers or be a typedef to a fixed-width or special type; inspect the typedef to confirm there are no qualifiers (e.g. volatile/const) or range constraints that would affect whether Status can vary.
- OS_Application_Startup (caller and its call-site(s) passing Status): The invariance check requires examination of every call site to see what argument is passed for Status. The static call graph shows OS_Application_Startup as the caller; its code/expressions determine whether the argument is a compile-time or run-time constant (invariant).
- All other call-sites of OS_ApplicationExit (if any): If there are additional callers (static graph may be incomplete), those call sites must be inspected as well — a single caller passing a constant would make the controlling expression effectively invariant in the deployed code path.
- UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData and UT_ExecuteBasicHandler: The static call graph lists these as callees of OS_ApplicationExit (test instrumentation/wrappers). Their bodies must be checked to ensure they do not modify the Status value or otherwise change program flow before the if, or that instrumentation does not replace the comparison with an invariant. If such wrappers are present in the build being analyzed, they can affect whether the controlling expression is invariant.
